6. Path to Citizenship

If you have been living in Armenia permanently for the past three years,
you are eligible to apply for Armenian citizenship. However, the term
"permanent resident" is not clearly defined by the Citizenship Law. In
practice, the police will accept and process a citizenship application
if the applicant has maintained an Armenian residence permit (temporary,
permanent, or special) during the three-year period.
In addition to the residency requirement, you will need to pass a test
on your knowledge of the Armenian Constitution. This is a
multiple-choice test with 33 questions, and you only need to answer 17
of them correctly to pass. The test is administered in Armenian, and you
will be asked to fill out a biographic form in Armenian as well. This
means that you may need to spend some time (perhaps a couple of months)
learning basic Armenian.
It is important to note that meeting the above requirements does not
guarantee that your citizenship application will be approved. If your
application is rejected, you can reapply after one year. Additionally,
if your application is rejected, you can appeal the decision in court.
However, administrative court proceedings are likely to take up to one
year or even longer.

7. Other Practical Information

[]

Investing in Real Estate, Bank Deposits and Other Assets

Armenia presents a diverse range of investment opportunities
characterized by advantageous conditions for both domestic and
international investors. Whether the focus is on real estate or
financial markets, the nation boasts a streamlined and investor-friendly
process, fostering increased capital inflow. 

Real Property

According to official statistics published by the Cadastral Office, the
real estate market in the center of Yerevan has demonstrated significant
growth. From April 2023 to March 2024, average prices per square meter
in the city center rose from $2,102 to $2,295, reflecting a 9.2% annual
increase. This steady upward trend is part of a larger surge observed
over the last decade, where prices soared from $1,021 in 2012 to $2,073
in 2023, totaling a 103% increase. This growth was particularly marked
by a dramatic 42.4% rise from 2021 to 2022.
The process of purchasing a property in Armenia is efficient and quick,
with the country ranking 13th out of 190 countries on the World Bank's
"Registering Property" index. It is even possible to buy properties
remotely without visiting the country.
Armenia does not have gift or estate taxes, and capital gains on the
sale of real property by an individual are generally not taxed. Property
tax rates range from 0% to 1% of the cadastral value, which is normally
significantly lower than the market value. Stamp duties are not
applicable, and only small official fees are paid, which do not depend
on the value of the property. Rental income up to 60 million Armenian
drams (approximately $155,000) per year is taxed at 10%, and rental
income exceeding that amount is taxed at 20%.
Foreigners can own 100% of real estate in Armenia, and they have the
same rights as locals to acquire, hold, lease, sell, bequeath, and
otherwise dispose of their property. There is no need for foreigners to
have a residence permit or any other links to Armenia. Overall, the real
estate market in Armenia offers great opportunities for foreign
investors seeking to diversify their portfolio and take advantage of a
growing economy.
You might want to consider buying off-plan property from real estate
developers and see non-taxable capital gains of 20-30% after the
construction is completed. There are many construction projects to
choose from, and you can find more information on websites such
as ArmEconomBank, ACBA Bank, Inecobank, Ameriabank, Red Invest Group,
and Construction.am.

Land and Farming
Lands in Armenia are classified according to their designated usage
(zoning), including agricultural, residential, industrial, energy,
forest, and more. Foreigners can directly own household and gardening
plots, lands designated for construction and maintenance of a homestead,
and residential and commercial development lands. Other types of land,
such as agricultural land, can be owned through a legal entity. Special
residence permit holders can own all types of land. There are some
restrictions on building on agricultural land, although small buildings
up to 30 sq. m. are allowed. In most rural communities, structures of up
to 300 sq. m. can be built on land exceeding 10,000 sq. m. It may also
be possible to change the zoning of land with the help of the local
municipality.
If you are interested in agricultural investments, you might consider
fruit farming or wine growing, which are one of the oldest economic
sectors in Armenia, with over 60,000 active entities in this industry.
The most popular forms of cultivation are grape, apricot, and peach. You
may choose to buy an existing farm or set up a new one, and you may be
eligible for a government subsidy. Two types of subsidies are available:
compensation of up to 50% of costs incurred in setting up a vineyard
(orchard) or a low-interest rate loan (2%) for a maximum amount of $2.9
million for vineyards, $5 million for orchards, and $4.7 million for
berry farms.

Stocks, Bonds, and Bank Deposits

If you are interested in investing in small and medium-sized businesses,
you can find offers on the Invest in Armenia
website: https://investin.am/investment-projects/. The Armenian stock
exchange also lists a few large
companies: https://amx.am/en/instruments/shares.
Although few companies are listed on the Armenian stock exchange, many
issue corporate bonds with relatively high yields (in excess of 11% in
local currency and 6% in USD). The Armenian government also issues both
short-term and long-term bonds, typically with annual interest rates
above 10%. You can find more information on the stock exchange website
and at moneymarket.am.
Interest paid on bank deposits in Armenia is relatively high, with
annual rates up to 10% for local currency deposits and 5% for USD
deposits. Deposits can also be made in euros and Russian Rubles, and
information on current deposit interest rates is available
at moneymarket.am. Although the Armenian dram has appreciated against
the USD by around 20% in 2022, exchange rates have been mostly stable
over the last few decades. Banks typically withhold a 10% tax on
interest payments. You can also find information on current prices of
gold bars (ranging from 1 gram to 1,000 grams) at moneymarket.am. Most
banks offer safety box services, allowing you to purchase gold bars and
keep them in a secure location.
All banks in Armenia are licensed and closely regulated by the Central
Bank of Armenia. A deposit insurance system is also in place, covering
deposits up to AMD 16 million (around $41,000) for local currency
deposits and AMD 7 million (around $18,000) for foreign currency
deposits. However, the system has never been used as there have been no
bank runs in recent history.

[]

Banking and Financial Services

Armenia has a well-established banking system, with 18 privately owned
banks regulated by the Central Bank. Among them, HSBC is an
international bank, while many local banks have foreign capital from
countries such as Russia (VTB), France (ACBA), Lebanon (Byblos, ID),
Argentina (Converse), Iran (Mellat), and others. Armenian banks offer
modern banking services, including online and mobile banking, debit and
credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, AmEx), accounts in various currencies
(USD, EUR, CHF, GBP, CAD, AED, RUR, JPY), gold metal accounts, wealth
management, private banking, and safety deposit boxes. They also have
low charges, strong privacy, and high-quality customer service.

[]

Healthcare and Insurance

In Armenia, individuals are not required by law to have health
insurance. However, all six licensed insurance companies offer health
insurance, with annual rates usually ranging between $300 to $600 per
person. These companies are SIL Insurance, Liga Insurance, Nairi
Insurance, Ingo Armenia, Reso, and Armenia Insurance.

[]

Company Registration

Setting up an LLC in Armenia is a quick and uncomplicated process, which
can be completed entirely remotely. There are no limitations on foreign
ownership or management of companies, no minimum investment
requirements, and no renewal fees to worry about. Shareholders are
afforded limited liability and can utilize the LLC structure for
purposes of asset protection or tax optimization. Armenia also boasts
favorable tax regulations for small businesses, with many being
completely exempt from taxes. Furthermore, IT companies can benefit from
special tax incentives.
Benefits: Registering an LLC in Armenia has several advantages,
including:

-   Fast registration process (typically within a couple of days)
-   Shareholders enjoy limited liability
-   Minimal documentation requirements (only passports are needed)
-   No restrictions on foreign ownership or directorship
-   No minimum capital requirements
-   No need to engage local partners, agents, managers, secretaries,
    etc.
-   Permanent existence with no renewal fees
-   Bank accounts available in various currencies
-   No restrictions on repatriation of profits and capital

For more information, please see the page on incorporation.
Taxation: Armenia offers favorable tax rates for small businesses. Many
types of businesses with annual sales below AMD 24 million (equivalent
to around $62,000 as of March 2023) are exempt from income tax. Other
businesses with annual sales below AMD 115 million (around $297,000) are
also exempt from income tax but are subject to a sales tax (turnover
tax) of 5% or less. Newly registered IT companies and firms operating in
free economic zones, industrial zones, and certain border towns and
villages are also eligible for tax exemptions.
An LLC registered in Armenia is considered a tax resident of Armenia and
is taxed on its worldwide income. Tax rates are generally the same
regardless of whether income comes from Armenia or another country.
Asset Protection: An Armenian LLC can be used as a holding company for
assets. Setting up a tax-exempt "microbusiness" LLC can be advantageous
for receiving passive income, such as dividends, of up to AMD 24 million
(around $62,000) annually. Additionally, income from the sale of
financial assets is not subject to taxation, regardless of the amount.
However, it is important to avoid being classified as an "investment
company," which requires licensing.
While it is possible to use an LLC to own real estate in Armenia or
other countries, Armenian tax laws generally make it more beneficial to
own such property as an individual to avoid capital gains tax on sales
between individuals.
Armenian law does not recognize trusts, so assets are typically held
through an LLC or other corporate structures such as a joint-stock
company, foundation, or consumer cooperative. Nominee and corporate
shareholders and directors are allowed, but companies must file annual
statements disclosing the ultimate beneficial owners (UBO).

[]

Marriage Registration

Foreigners can get married in Armenia without any requirement to live or
have ties to the country. The registration process is typically quick
and can be completed in as little as two business days. However, both
individuals need to provide a "non-marriage" certificate from their
country of permanent residence to confirm their marital status. If a
non-marriage certificate cannot be obtained, an affidavit may be used
instead. These documents must be legalized, either by Apostille or
consular legalization, and translated into Armenian before they can be
submitted to the Armenian Ministry of Justice. Remote registration with
a power of attorney may also be possible.

[]

Driving License

Obtaining an Armenian driving license is a two-step process that
involves taking a computer-based driving theory test and a practical
driving test. The theory test questions are available in Armenian,
Russian, English, Arabic, and Farsi. There are a total of 1,116
questions, and the test consists of 20 questions with only two incorrect
answers allowed. To register for the test, you can visit the
website roadpolice.am and wait for notification about the time and place
of the test. If you pass the theory test, you will be allowed to take
the driving test immediately. In addition, it is possible to exchange
your foreign driving license for an Armenian one if your license is
issued by a country that is party to the 1968 Vienna Convention.

Your Ultimate Checklist for Obtaining an Entry Visa for Foreigners in Armenia

As a foreigner, before travelling to any country entry requirements need
to be taken into account. In this article, we will provide you with a
comprehensive checklist that will guide you through the process of
obtaining an entry visa for foreigners in Armenia.

[]

Introduction to Entry Visa for Foreigners in Armenia

An entry visa is a document that grants you permission to enter a
foreign country for a specific period. For Armenia, there are a few visa
regimes and the type you are eligible for depends on the citizenship you
hold.

Visa-free regime

Citizens of the below-mentioned countries are visa-exempt; thus, they do
not need to apply for a visa and can stay in Armenia for up to 180 days
within a year.
1.Albania
2.Andorra
3.Argentina
4.Australia
5.Austria
6.Belarus
7.Belgium
8.Brazil
9.Bulgaria
10.Croatia
11.Cyprus
12.Czechia
13.Denmark
14.Ecuador
15.Estonia
16.Finland
17.France
18.Georgia
19.Germany
20.Greece
21.Holy See (Vatical City State)
22.Hong Kong (SAR China)
23.Hungary
24.Iceland
25.Ireland
26.Italy
27.Japan
28.Kazakhstan
29.Kuwait
30.Kyrgyzstan
31.Liechtenstein
32.Lithuania
33.Latvia
34.Luxembourg
35.Macao
36.Malta
37.Monaco
38.Montenegro
39.Netherlands
40.New Zealand
41.Norway
42.Poland
43.Portugal
44.Qatar
45.Republic of Korea
46.Republic of Moldova
47.Romania
48.Russian Federation
49.San Marino
50.Serbia
51.Singapore
52.Slovakia
53.Slovenia
54.Spain
55.Sweden
56.Switzerland
57.Tajikistan
58.Ukraine
59.United Arab Emirates
60.United Kingdom
61.United States of America
62.Uruguay
63.Uzbekistan
Citizens of the People’s Republic of China and the Islamic Republic of
Iran are also visa-exempt; however, they can stay in Armenia for up to
90 days within any 180-day period.

Please note that citizens of these countries can only legally extend
their stay in Armenia by getting a residence permit in Armenia (based on
work/business/studies).

Visa on arrival

Citizens of the below-mentioned countries can either get a visa on
arrival or choose to apply for a visa beforehand at an Armenian embassy
or through e-visa platform. These citizens can choose to either get a 21
or 120-day visa.

1.Antigua and Barbuda
2.Bahamas
3.Barbados
4.Bosnia and Herzegovina
5.Canada
6.Chile
7.Democratic People’s republic of Korea (North)
8.Dominica
9.Dominican Republic
10.Israel
11.Jordan
12.Lebanon
13.Mexico
14.North Macedonia
15.Oman
16.Panama
17.Peru
18.Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
19.South Africa
20.Thailand
21.Turkiye

Visa at an embassy or E-Visa

For citizens of these countries, it is again possible to apply for a
visa to Armenia at an Armenian embassy or through the e-visa platform
online (find information about the e-visa application documents and the
fees below). These citizens can qualify for a visa on arrival only if
they hold a valid visa or a temporary or permanent residence card from
an EU/Schengen country, or one of the GCC countries (UAE, Qatar, Kuwait,
Saudi Arabia, Oman, Bahrain), USA, UK, Canada, Russia, Australia, New
Zealand, Japan, or South Korea.

Citizens of the below-mentioned countries will need an invitation letter
from Armenia before you can obtain a visa at the Armenian embassy. These
citizens cannot apply for a visa through the e-visa platform even after
they get an approved invitation letter.

Invitations can be presented both by legal entities registered in
Armenia or individuals. In case of individuals the invitations are
submitted at the Migration and Citizenship Service of the Ministry of
Internal Affairs of the Republic of Armenia.

E-visa application documents

To apply for an e-visa to Armenia, citizens of the qualified countries
need to attach the following documents:
•  valid passport copy
•  a passport-size photo
•  residence address and phone number
•  occupation (company and the position)
•  residence address in Armenia, contact phone number
•  arrival date
•  accommodation booking (preferable)
•  other country visas/residence permits, if any
•  flight tickets or reservation, if any
•  proof of funds, if any

E-Visa Processing Time and Fees

The processing time and fees for an entry visa for foreigners in Armenia
vary depending on the type of visa and the duration of stay. The e-visa
fees are $7 and $34 for a 21 and 120-day visas respectively, and the
processing time usually takes 3 business days.

Extension of Entry Visa for Foreigners in Armenia

Visitor visas are extended by the Migration and Citizenship Service of
the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Armenia.
Armenian visas are issued for a maximum of 120 days with the possibility
to extend for another 60 days if no other term is defined by
international agreements of the Republic of Armenia. The government fee
for each day of extension is AMD 500 (around USD 1,5). 

Conclusion and Additional Resources for Entry Visa Application

For additional resources and information on the visa application
process, you can visit the official website of the Ministry of Foreign
Affairs of the Republic of Armenia or contact the Armenian embassy or
consulate in your country.

In case after visiting Armenia you decide to stay longer than your visa
validity period, you can review the options to get a residence permit in
Armenia.

Residency for Digital Nomads in Armenia 2024 

Becoming a resident of Armenia is a great opportunity for digital
nomads, freelancers, remote workers, and online business owners, and it
is easier than you might think. Armenia offers temporary and permanent
residence permits to such individuals and their families. Plus, if you
hold a residence permit, you may be eligible for an Armenian passport
(citizenship) after just three years of residency. The application
process for a residence permit is also quite straightforward. You can
apply remotely, and typically, all you need is a valid passport (more
details on the process and requirements below). Unlike other countries,
Armenia does not require you to stay in the country, provide police
clearance certificates, insurance policies, bank account statements, or
travel tickets.

Stay informed with our newsletter—get the latest news, legal updates, and expert advice on citizenship

Sign Up

[]

Table of Contents

1.  Benefits of Investment-Based Residency
2.  Eligibility and Application Process
3.  Residency Options and Requirements
4.  Financial and Legal Aspects
5.  Renewal and Long-Term Stay Considerations
6.  Living in Armenia

1. Benefits of Residency for Digital Nomads

Obtaining an Armenian residence permit presents a wealth of advantages
for individuals seeking residency in a country with a rich cultural
heritage and robust economic opportunities. Here are the key benefits
and procedural aspects of securing residency in Armenia:

Ease of Procedure

-   Remote Application Process: Applicants can secure their Armenian
    residency remotely, requiring only a passport and a health
    certificate. This streamlined process enables individuals from
    around the globe to apply without needing to be physically present
    in Armenia initially.
-   Minimal Documentation Required: Applicants need only provide their
    passport and a medical certificate alongside documents supporting
    their legal basis for application.

Lifestyle and Legal Privileges

-   Family Inclusion: The residence permit extends eligibility to family
    members, including spouses, children (minor and adult), siblings,
    and grandparents, making it a family-friendly option.
-   Economic and Cultural Benefits: Armenia boasts a rapidly growing
    economy, with a 8.7% GDP growth in 2023. The country offers
    investment opportunities in high-interest banking and a thriving
    real estate market where foreign land ownership is permitted. The
    capital, Yerevan, is noted for its safety, low cost of living,
    high-speed internet, affordable healthcare, and exceptional cuisine.
    From its UNESCO World Heritage Sites to the stunning views of Mount
    Ararat, Armenia's natural and cultural offerings enrich the lives of
    its residents.
-   Legal and Social Advantages: Residents of Armenia enjoy all
    constitutional rights and freedoms afforded to citizens, except for
    political rights. These include rights to healthcare, social
    security, education, property, and privacy, along with freedoms of
    speech, conscience, religion, and belief. Importantly, residents are
    exempt from mandatory military service.
-   Global Connectivity: Armenia maintains strong international
    relationships, especially with Western nations such as those in the
    European Union and the USA. It also has a visa-free regime with
    countries like Russia, Iran, and China, enhancing the travel freedom
    of its residents.
-   Investment and Banking Opportunities: As a resident, individuals can
    access diverse banking services and investment opportunities.
    Permanent property and land ownership rights are significant
    incentives for those looking to invest in real estate.

Path to Citizenship

-   Path to Citizenship: After three years of residency, individuals may
    qualify for Armenian citizenship, contingent upon government
    approval.

-   Dual Citizenship: If an individual opts to become an Armenian
    citizen, the country expressly permits dual citizenship, allowing
    one to retain their original nationality.

2. Eligibility and Application Process

[]

Qualification Criteria

If you are a digital nomad, freelancer, remote worker, or online
business owner looking to become a resident of Armenia, you will need to
meet certain requirements. Specifically, you must be engaged in business
activities in Armenia, which means registering with the Armenian tax
office as a sole proprietor (or register an LLC). However, your work
does not have to be connected to Armenia, and there are no requirements
to have Armenian clients or suppliers.

It is important to note that you will need to report at least some
income and pay taxes in Armenia. The tax rates will depend on your
income or sales, with independent service providers typically opting for
the "turnover tax" regime, which levies a 5% tax on reported income.
Under the "microbusiness" regime, it may be possible to pay 0% tax if
your annual income does not exceed around $60,000, though not all types
of activities qualify for this treatment. You may also be subject to
social (pension) contributions and military stamp duties after your
residence permit is issued.
For example, let us say you offer online classes. Since educational
services can be treated as a "microbusiness," you will be exempt from
taxes on income of up to around $60,000 per year, and you will not have
to make social (pension) contributions. However, you will need to pay
monthly military stamp duties of $4 to $25 after your residence permit
is issued.
On the other hand, if you are a business consultant, consulting services
cannot be treated as a "microbusiness," so you will have to pay a 5%
turnover tax on your income of up to $296,000. If you report income from
consulting services of $1,000 per month, you will pay $50 in turnover
tax (5% of $1,000) and a flat fee of $13 in income tax. After your
residence permit is issued, you will also need to pay a flat social
(pension) contribution of $13 and a monthly military stamp duty of $5.
Your total monthly tax bill will be $81 ($50 + $13 + $13 + $5).

+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
|                 | Microbusiness   | Turnover Tax    | Income Tax      |
+=================+=================+=================+=================+
| Annual Sales    | < $60,000       | < $296,000      | > $296,000      |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
| Tax Rate        | 0%              | $13 per month + | 18% on profit   |
|                 |                 | 5% on sales     |                 |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
| Social          | 0               | $13 per month   | $188 per month  |
| (Pension)       |                 |                 |                 |
| Contribution    |                 |                 |                 |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
| Military Stamp  | $4-$25 per      | $4-$25 per      | $25 per month   |
| Duty            | month           | month           |                 |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+

[]

Step-by-Step Guide

If you are interested in obtaining an Armenian residence permit, you
will need to follow these steps:
Step 1: Travel to Armenia or mail the necessary documents to Armenia
(including a power of attorney and a legalized passport copy or the
original passport) if you are applying remotely.
Step 2: Register with the tax office as a sole proprietor and obtain a
taxpayer identification number (2-3 days).
Step 3: Report income from business or employment to the tax office and
pay taxes (approximately 3-6 weeks).
Step 4: File your residence permit application. If you are applying
remotely, you will need to mail your original passport. The passport
will be returned to you after a few days (1-2 days or approximately 2-3
weeks for remote applications).
Step 5: Wait for your residence permit application to be examined and
approved (30-50 days).
Step 6: We will collect your residence permit and have it delivered or
mailed to you (1 day).
The whole process typically takes between two to four months, depending
on the type of application (remote or in-person) and your individual
circumstances.
To apply, you will need a valid passport, and a medical check
certificate and photographs may also be required. You will not need to
provide proof of address or employment, police clearance certificates,
bank account statements, reference letters, health/travel insurance, or
tickets.
Keep in mind that you will need to budget for legal fees, as well as
other expenses like government fees, mailing, translation, and
notarization. For more information, feel free to contact us.

[]

Remote Applications: Procedure and Requirements

If you are applying for an Armenian residence permit, your lawyer or
representative can file the application remotely. However, on the day of
the application, we will need to present your original passport to the
immigration officer. This means that if you are applying remotely, you
will need to mail your passport to Armenia via a courier service like
FedEx, DHL, or UPS for a few days. Your passport will be mailed back to
you immediately after the application is filed.

[]

Family Residency

If you hold an Armenian residence permit, your immediate family members
may also be eligible for residency. Specifically, you can sponsor your
spouse, your children (whether they are minors or adults, with no age
restrictions), and your parents (also with no age restrictions). You do
not need to demonstrate that your family members are financially
dependent on you.
Furthermore, if you have a permanent (long-term) or special residence
permit, you can also sponsor your siblings, grandparents, and
grandchildren.

happy that Vardanyan & Partners has been able to do just that.

John B.

[][][][][]

Their meticulous attention to detail, unwavering dedication, and
commitment to ensuring their clients' needs are met are truly admirable.
I strongly recommend Vardanyan & Partners for their exceptional legal
services.

Ali E.

3. Residency Options and Requirements

[]

Types of Permits

Applications for temporary (1-year) or permanent (5-year) residence
permits must be filed at the Immigration Office. Please note that
Armenian embassies typically do not process residence permit
applications, except in the case of a special 10-year residence permit.

[]

[]

Temporary residence permit card

[]

[]

Permanent residence permit card

[]

[]

Special residence permit/ Special passport

[]

Documentation and Legal Requirements

To apply, you will need a valid passport, and a medical check
certificate and photographs may also be required. You will not need to
provide proof of address or employment, police clearance certificates,
bank account statements, reference letters, health/travel insurance, or
tickets.

4. Financial and Legal Aspects

[]

Taxation for Digital Nomads

It is important to note that obtaining a residence permit (temporary,
permanent, or special) does not automatically make you a "tax resident."
Tax residency is regulated by tax laws, not immigration laws. In
general, you become a tax resident of Armenia by spending more than 183
days in the country in a year. This means that it is possible to hold a
residence permit without becoming a tax resident, and vice versa.
Please be aware that if you are employed as a worker or are a "private
entrepreneur" in Armenia, you may be required to begin making social
(pension) and military contributions once you have obtained your
residence permit.
Armenia does not typically tax individuals' capital gains on the sale of
securities or real estate, or other assets, regardless of whether those
gains are generated in Armenia or elsewhere. Certain forms of income,
such as insurance and pension payments, are also exempt from taxes.
Additionally, there are no taxes on gifts, inheritance, or net worth.
However, there is no general rule that exempts a tax resident from
paying taxes on income generated outside of Armenia.
You may also be able to obtain documents such as proof of registered
address in Armenia, a social security number, a taxpayer identification
number, a tax residency certificate, or a certificate of permanent
residency.

Taxpayer Identification Number
Individuals receiving profits from commercial organizations are mandated
to obtain a Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN). This is imperative, as
the distribution of profits entails the obligation to remit income tax
on dividends, necessitating the possession of a TIN for tax payment
purposes. Furthermore, certain foreign banks may request the Taxpayer
Identification Number as a means to authenticate their association with
the Republic of Armenia.
The application process primarily involves the submission of a TIN
application along with a copy of the passport.

Tax Residency Certificate
In general, an individual can become a tax resident of Armenia if their
stay in the country extends to 183 days or more. Alternatively, a
petition can be submitted to the tax office to procure a tax residency
certificate, even if the stipulated duration of 183 days is not met.
However, the application must substantiate that the center of vital
interest is situated in Armenia, signifying that personal or business
affiliations with Armenia outweigh those with any other country. It is
crucial to note that such certificates are issued exclusively for a
specific tax year and explicitly cite the pertinent double tax treaty.
To initiate the application for a tax residency certificate, the
applicant is required to submit a comprehensive set of documents. These
include statements detailing income from foreign sources, copies of all
passport pages, a calculation table reflecting the individual's presence
within the Republic of Armenia, or a written justification outlining the
localization of the center of vital interests within the territory of
the Republic of Armenia, supported by relevant documentation.
The issuance of the tax residency certificate is typically completed
within two business days.

[]

Costs of Obtaining a Residence Permit

The government fees for obtaining a residence permit vary between $270
to $390, depending on the type of permit. Immediate relatives of
Armenian nationals are generally exempt from paying government fees, and
reduced rates apply to US nationals. In the event that the application
for a residence permit is rejected (but not if withdrawn by the
applicant), the government fees are refundable.
Please be aware that in addition to government fees, you may also incur
expenses related to document translation, medical checks, photographs,
etc. If you plan to hire a lawyer to represent you before the
immigration authorities, legal fees will also apply.

+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
| Residence       | Temporary       | Permanent       | Special         |
| Permit          | (Short-Term)    | (Long-Term)     | Passport        |
+=================+=================+=================+=================+
| Validity        | 1 year,         | 5 years,        | 10 years,       |
|                 | extendable      | extendable      | extendable      |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+
| Government Fees | $270 (AMD       | $360 (AMD       | $390 (AMD       |
| (Approx.)       | 105,000)        | 140,000)        | 150,000)        |
+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+

5. Renewal and Long-Term Stay Considerations

[]

Renewal Process

Residence permits must be renewed (extended) periodically. Temporary
permits can be renewed annually, while permanent (long-term) and special
residence permits can be renewed every five and ten years, respectively.
The application for renewal must be submitted no later than 30 days
before the expiration of the current permit. In the case of special
permits, it is recommended to apply at least 60 days before the
expiration. If there are family members (dependents), the main applicant
should apply even earlier to allow sufficient time for processing both
their own and their dependents' applications.
Please note that currently, the Immigration Office requires all
appointments to be scheduled in advance through an online booking system
(https://e-request.am/en). The waiting periods for these appointments
may range from a few weeks to even longer, so it is important to
consider this factor when planning for an extension.
The renewal procedure is similar to that of the initial application. For
instance, a business owner would still need to be interviewed by an
immigration officer and show proof of active business operations, among
other requirements (refer to section 3 above for further information).
There are no restrictions on the number of times a residence permit can
be extended, and there is no requirement to spend a particular number of
days in Armenia to extend the residence permit. Moreover, it is possible
to apply for an extension remotely.

[]

Path to Long-term Residency or Citizenship

If you have been living in Armenia permanently for the past three years,
you are eligible to apply for Armenian citizenship. However, the term
"permanent resident" is not clearly defined by the Citizenship Law. In
practice, the police will accept and process a citizenship application
if the applicant has maintained an Armenian residence permit (temporary,
permanent, or special) during the three-year period.
In addition to the residency requirement, you will need to pass a test
on your knowledge of the Armenian Constitution. This is a
multiple-choice test with 33 questions, and you only need to answer 17
of them correctly to pass. The test is administered in Armenian, and you
will be asked to fill out a biographic form in Armenian as well. This
means that you may need to spend some time (perhaps a couple of months)
learning basic Armenian.
It is important to note that meeting the above requirements does not
guarantee that your citizenship application will be approved. If your
application is rejected, you can reapply after one year. Additionally,
if your application is rejected, you can appeal the decision in court.
However, administrative court proceedings are likely to take up to one
year or even longer.

6. Living in Armenia

[]

Community and Networking

Vibrant expatriate groups such as the Armenian Repatriates Network and
Expats in Republic of Armenia provide excellent resources for networking
and integration.

[]

Renting or Buying Property

According to official statistics published by the Cadastral Office, the
real estate market in the center of Yerevan has demonstrated significant
growth. From April 2023 to March 2024, average prices per square meter
in the city center rose from $2,102 to $2,295, reflecting a 9.2% annual
increase. This steady upward trend is part of a larger surge observed
over the last decade, where prices soared from $1,021 in 2012 to $2,073
in 2023, totaling a 103% increase. This growth was particularly marked
by a dramatic 42.4% rise from 2021 to 2022.
The process of purchasing a property in Armenia is efficient and quick,
with the country ranking 13th out of 190 countries on the World Bank's
"Registering Property" index. It is even possible to buy properties
remotely without visiting the country.
Armenia does not have gift or estate taxes, and capital gains on the
sale of real property by an individual are generally not taxed. Property
tax rates range from 0% to 1% of the cadastral value, which is normally
significantly lower than the market value. Stamp duties are not
applicable, and only small official fees are paid, which do not depend
on the value of the property. Rental income up to 60 million Armenian
drams (approximately $155,000) per year is taxed at 10%, and rental
income exceeding that amount is taxed at 20%.
Foreigners can own 100% of real estate in Armenia, and they have the
same rights as locals to acquire, hold, lease, sell, bequeath, and
otherwise dispose of their property. There is no need for foreigners to
have a residence permit or any other links to Armenia. Overall, the real
estate market in Armenia offers great opportunities for foreign
investors seeking to diversify their portfolio and take advantage of a
growing economy.
You might want to consider buying off-plan property from real estate
developers and see non-taxable capital gains of 20-30% after the
construction is completed. There are many construction projects to
choose from, and you can find more information on websites such
as ArmEconomBank, ACBA Bank, Inecobank, Ameriabank, Red Invest Group,
and Construction.am.

[]

Banking and Financial Services

Armenia has a well-established banking system, with 18 privately owned
banks regulated by the Central Bank. Among them, HSBC is an
international bank, while many local banks have foreign capital from
countries such as Russia (VTB), France (ACBA), Lebanon (Byblos, ID),
Argentina (Converse), Iran (Mellat), and others. Armenian banks offer
modern banking services, including online and mobile banking, debit and
credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, AmEx), accounts in various currencies
(USD, EUR, CHF, GBP, CAD, AED, RUR, JPY), gold metal accounts, wealth
management, private banking, and safety deposit boxes. They also have
low charges, strong privacy, and high-quality customer service.

[]

Healthcare and Insurance

In Armenia, individuals are not required by law to have health
insurance. However, all six licensed insurance companies offer health
insurance, with annual rates usually ranging between $300 to $600 per
person. These companies are SIL Insurance, Liga Insurance, Nairi
Insurance, Ingo Armenia, Reso, and Armenia Insurance.

[]

Company Registration

Setting up an LLC in Armenia is a quick and uncomplicated process, which
can be completed entirely remotely. There are no limitations on foreign
ownership or management of companies, no minimum investment
requirements, and no renewal fees to worry about. Shareholders are
afforded limited liability and can utilize the LLC structure for
purposes of asset protection or tax optimization. Armenia also boasts
favorable tax regulations for small businesses, with many being
completely exempt from taxes. Furthermore, IT companies can benefit from
special tax incentives.
Benefits: Registering an LLC in Armenia has several advantages,
including:

-   Fast registration process (typically within a couple of days)
-   Shareholders enjoy limited liability
-   Minimal documentation requirements (only passports are needed)
-   No restrictions on foreign ownership or directorship
-   No minimum capital requirements
-   No need to engage local partners, agents, managers, secretaries,
    etc.
-   Permanent existence with no renewal fees
-   Bank accounts available in various currencies
-   No restrictions on repatriation of profits and capital

For more information, please see the page on incorporation.
Taxation: Armenia offers favorable tax rates for small businesses. Many
types of businesses with annual sales below AMD 24 million (equivalent
to around $62,000 as of March 2023) are exempt from income tax. Other
businesses with annual sales below AMD 115 million (around $297,000) are
also exempt from income tax but are subject to a sales tax (turnover
tax) of 5% or less. Newly registered IT companies and firms operating in
free economic zones, industrial zones, and certain border towns and
villages are also eligible for tax exemptions.
An LLC registered in Armenia is considered a tax resident of Armenia and
is taxed on its worldwide income. Tax rates are generally the same
regardless of whether income comes from Armenia or another country.
Asset Protection: An Armenian LLC can be used as a holding company for
assets. Setting up a tax-exempt "microbusiness" LLC can be advantageous
for receiving passive income, such as dividends, of up to AMD 24 million
(around $62,000) annually. Additionally, income from the sale of
financial assets is not subject to taxation, regardless of the amount.
However, it is important to avoid being classified as an "investment
company," which requires licensing.
While it is possible to use an LLC to own real estate in Armenia or
other countries, Armenian tax laws generally make it more beneficial to
own such property as an individual to avoid capital gains tax on sales
between individuals.
Armenian law does not recognize trusts, so assets are typically held
through an LLC or other corporate structures such as a joint-stock
company, foundation, or consumer cooperative. Nominee and corporate
shareholders and directors are allowed, but companies must file annual
statements disclosing the ultimate beneficial owners (UBO).

[]

Marriage Registration

Foreigners can get married in Armenia without any requirement to live or
have ties to the country. The registration process is typically quick
and can be completed in as little as two business days. However, both
individuals need to provide a "non-marriage" certificate from their
country of permanent residence to confirm their marital status. If a
non-marriage certificate cannot be obtained, an affidavit may be used
instead. These documents must be legalized, either by Apostille or
consular legalization, and translated into Armenian before they can be
submitted to the Armenian Ministry of Justice. Remote registration with
a power of attorney may also be possible.

[]

Driving License

Obtaining an Armenian driving license is a two-step process that
involves taking a computer-based driving theory test and a practical
driving test. The theory test questions are available in Armenian,
Russian, English, Arabic, and Farsi. There are a total of 1,116
questions, and the test consists of 20 questions with only two incorrect
answers allowed. To register for the test, you can visit the
website roadpolice.am and wait for notification about the time and place
of the test. If you pass the theory test, you will be allowed to take
the driving test immediately. In addition, it is possible to exchange
your foreign driving license for an Armenian one if your license is
issued by a country that is party to the 1968 Vienna Convention.

Real Estate Acquisition in Armenia 

Armenia presents a compelling destination for investors and individuals
seeking to reside in the country. Its appeal lies in its economic
growth, rich cultural heritage, natural beauty, distinctive cuisine, low
taxation, safety, and the increasing value of properties in central
Yerevan. Moreover, Armenia permits foreigners to own real estate with
potential investment opportunities and tax advantages. The country's low
crime rate and the absence of taxes on real estate transactions, capital
gains, gifts, or inheritances enhance its attractiveness. Real estate
investments may also lead to immigration benefits, such as residence
permits and potentially citizenship.
Nonetheless, considering real estate investments in Armenia requires
careful planning and due diligence. Engaging a local lawyer with
expertise in the field can be invaluable. They can assist with
navigating the intricacies of the investment process, reviewing and
preparing necessary documents, facilitating payments, and ensuring
proper registrations.

Rest assured, any information you provide will be treated with the
utmost confidentiality. We firmly believe in the principle of data
privacy. That means we will not sell, rent, or lease our contact lists
to any third party, and your personal details will never be handed over
to individuals, government agencies, or companies.

According to official statistics published by the Cadastral Office, the
real estate market in the center of Yerevan has demonstrated significant
growth, with a notable increase in the last year. From April 2023 to
March 2024, average prices per square meter in the city center rose from
$2,102 to $2,295, reflecting a 9.2% annual increase. This steady upward
trend is part of a larger surge observed over the last decade, where
prices soared from $1,021 in 2012 to $2,073 in 2023, totaling a 103%
increase. This growth was particularly marked by a dramatic 42.4% rise
from 2021 to 2022.

Key factors for recent price increases:

1. Growing Economy: Armenia's GDP grew by 8․7% in 2023.

2. Lower Mortgage Rates: Interest rates dropped from 18% to around 10.5%
and are expected to decrease further.

3. Rising Rental Demand: Tourism and urbanization drove higher demand
for rental properties.

4. Shift from Bank Deposits: Real estate became a more attractive
investment due to declining deposit interest rates.

5. Limited New Construction: Central Yerevan experienced limited new
dwelling construction.

[]

Foreign Ownership of Real Estate

Foreigners enjoy unrestricted ownership rights when it comes to real
estate in Armenia. They have the full spectrum of privileges, including
acquisition, retention, leasing, sale, inheritance, and other
property-related activities, on an equal footing with local residents.
Remarkably, there's no obligation for foreigners to secure a residence
permit or demonstrate any specific ties to Armenia.
Moreover, investing in real estate can open doors to securing a
temporary or permanent residence permit in Armenia, enhancing the appeal
of property investment for foreign individuals. However, it's important
to note that there is a unique restriction on foreign ownership that
applies solely to agricultural land. To navigate this restriction,
foreign investors may need to establish a legal entity and acquire
agricultural land under the entity's name.
Alternatively, foreign individuals with special residency status in
Armenia are permitted to directly own agricultural land.

[]

Ownership Structure

Sole Ownership

Regardless of your marital status, you have the option to purchase
property in Armenia under your sole name. In many countries, marital
laws dictate that assets acquired during marriage are jointly owned by
both spouses, regardless of the purchaser. Armenia follows a similar
approach. In the case of a married couple, civil law treats the property
as if it were jointly owned equally (50-50), unless the marriage
contract specifies otherwise. Thus, your spouse is considered a co-owner
of the property, even if their name is not on the purchase agreement.

Armenian law does not recognize "common-law marriages." If you cohabit
without marriage, your partner does not automatically gain permanent
occupation or ownership rights. Without a will, your partner also has no
inheritance rights.

If a single person in Armenia buys property and subsequently marries,
they can enter into a marriage contract to outline how the property is
handled within the terms of the contract.

Joint Ownership

Joint ownership arises when property is purchased by two or more
individuals, each holding a stake in the property based on their agreed
terms. For couples, this typically involves equal shares, but with more
purchasers, it can be proportional to their financial contributions,
e.g., 70% / 20% / 10%. In common law, this is similar to a 'tenancy in
common.'

All property owners have the right to participate in decisions related
to the property. The law requires unanimous decisions regarding the
property. Any owner or group of owners can request the sale of the
property, unless shares can be physically separated or other owners are
willing to buy those shares. If no agreement is reached, a court order
may be necessary to authorize the property's sale.

Owners can also sell or gift their share of the property. In the case of
a sale, they must offer existing owners a right of first refusal, which
does not apply to gifts or inheritances. Other owners have one month to
exercise their preemption rights.

Company Ownership

Property in Armenia can be purchased through a local or foreign limited
company with distinct legal identity from its shareholders. Reasons for
this approach include:

-   Allowing multiple individuals to purchase the property.
-   Ensuring stability and continuity in family property ownership and
    management.
-   Simplifying property transfer and ownership.
-   Mitigating constraints of inheritance laws.
-   Creating potential tax advantages.
-   Protecting the family home from business creditors.

However, it's essential to be aware of potential tax disadvantages,
particularly related to withholding taxes and capital gains tax, when
using this ownership structure.

[]

Real Estate Acquisition Process

[]

BENEFITS OF PROPERTY ACQUISITION IN ARMENIA

1. 100% Foreign Ownership

Armenia welcomes foreign investors with open arms, allowing them to have
complete ownership of real estate properties. Whether you want to
acquire, hold, lease, sell, bequeath, or otherwise manage your property,
you enjoy the same rights as local residents. There's no need for a
residence permit or any specific ties to Armenia. Even agricultural land
can be owned through a legal entity.

2. High Appreciation Rates

Investors in central Yerevan witnessed a remarkable increase in property
values, with a notable 34.5% surge in 2018-2019. This uptrend is
attributed to a growing economy and declining mortgage rates, making it
a lucrative market for potential appreciation.

3. High Rental Yield

Armenia's flourishing tourism industry is driving strong demand for
rental properties. This sector's vitality translates into attractive
rental yields for property owners.

4. Fast & Secure Registration

Streamlined processes make buying property in Armenia exceptionally
efficient. The country ranks 13th out of 190 nations on the World Bank's
"Registering Property" index, signifying both the speed and reliability
of its property registration system. Notably, it is even possible to
purchase properties remotely without visiting Armenia.

5. No Gift or Inheritance Taxes

Armenia stands out as a tax-friendly destination. It imposes no gift or
estate taxes, offering investors more flexibility in managing their
assets.

6. No Tax on Capital Gains

Individuals selling real property in Armenia typically enjoy tax
exemptions on capital gains, further enhancing the attractiveness of
property investments.

7. Low Property Taxes

Property taxes in Armenia are notably reasonable, typically ranging from
0% to 1% of the cadastral value, which tends to be lower than market
prices.

8. No Stamp Duties

Unlike many other countries, Armenia imposes no stamp duties on property
transactions. Only modest official fees are applicable, unrelated to the
property's value.

9. Residency & Citizenship Opportunities

Armenia extends residency options, including temporary and permanent
residency, along with special programs designed for foreign
businesspeople. Additionally, investors in real estate may qualify for
citizenship-by-exception, making Armenia an enticing destination for
those seeking immigration benefits.

[]

PAYMENT METHODS

1. Direct Bank Transfer

Payment via direct bank transfer is akin to cash transactions in terms
of risk for both parties. It's generally not recommended unless done
after ownership rights are officially registered.

[]

[]

Pros

-   []

    Secure payment through a bank

-   []

    Charges and fees may be minimized if both the seller and the buyer
    open accounts with the same bank

[]

[]

Cons

-   []

    Legal risks are the same as with a cash payment

-   []

    Payment possible only in local currency

-   []

    Bank may charge fees for currency conversion, transfer, cashing out
    the funds etc.

2. Bank Escrow Agreement

A bank escrow agreement involves three parties: the seller, the buyer,
and the escrow agent (a bank). The buyer opens an escrow account and
deposits the purchase amount. Once deposited, the funds are locked for a
predetermined period, such as 20 days. The seller gains access to the
funds only upon presenting proof of the buyer's registered ownership,
like an ownership certificate, to the bank. Failure to provide this
proof within the specified time allows the buyer to reclaim the funds.

Escrow accounts are commonly used in transactions involving mortgaged
property, as mortgage-holding banks often require funds to be deposited
in escrow before approving the sale.

[]

[]

Pros

-   []

    Secure payment through a bank

-   []

    Additional layer of protection offered by the escrow agent (bank)

-   []

    Minimal risks for both the buyer and the seller

[]

[]

Cons

-   []

    Bank will charge fees for opening the escrow account

-   []

    Bank will charge fees for currency conversion, transfer, cashing out
    the funds etc.

-   []

    Payment possible only in local currency

-   []

    Sellers are often not familiar with escrow accounts and are
    skeptical about them

3. Safety Deposit Box

In this method, the buyer deposits cash into a safety deposit box,
typically under the supervision of a trusted professional, like a lawyer
or realtor, who acts as an escrow agent. The seller gains access to the
deposit box once the new ownership is officially registered. If
registration doesn't occur within the agreed timeframe (e.g., 20 days),
the lawyer or realtor returns the funds to the buyer. The added benefit
is that the safety deposit box is usually located in a bank, which can
assist in counting the money and verifying its authenticity.

[]

[]

Pros

-   []

    Minimal risks for both the buyer and the seller

-   []

    Additional layer of protection offered by the lawyer/realtor

-   []

    Charges for renting a safety deposit box are lower compared to bank
    transfer

-   []

    No control over use of foreign currency

[]

[]

Cons

-   []

    Difficulties with cashing out large amounts

-   []

    Bank may charge fees for counting/verifying notes

-   []

    Risks of fraud by the lawyer/realtor

Direct payments via bank transfer are generally discouraged unless
conducted after ownership rights are legally registered. To minimize
risks for both buyers and sellers, opting for an escrow account or a
bank safety deposit box is recommended. These methods provide security
and ensure that funds are only released when the required ownership
documentation is in place, safeguarding the interests of all parties
involved in the real estate transaction.

[]

APPRAISAL AND SURVEY

Foreign buyers in Armenia should be cautious to avoid overpaying for
real estate. To make informed decisions, consider the following
recommendations:

1. Valuation Reports

A valuation report is an invaluable tool for understanding the correct
price to pay for a property, especially if it requires renovations.
Numerous licensed agencies in Armenia employ qualified staff to conduct
property appraisals. While not a substitute for a survey report, an
appraisal can still assess wear and tear, potentially offering insights
into the property's condition. Appraisals are typically based on:

-   Sales Comparison Approach: Evaluating selling prices of similar
    properties.
-   Cost Approach: Estimating the cost of purchasing similar land and
    constructing a comparable building.
-   Income Approach: Assessing expected annual rental income.

2. Building Surveys

Armenian law does not mandate sellers to commission surveys. However, it
is advisable for buyers to consider this option. Although there is no
specific building surveying profession in Armenia, you can engage a
local architect, engineer, or skilled builder (electrician, plumber,
etc.) to perform this task. A comprehensive survey can help minimize
risks associated with property purchases and serve as a valuable
negotiation tool.

3. Property Measurement

It's prudent to measure the property, particularly land, independently.
Cadastral documents may not always provide entirely accurate area
measurements, and property boundaries may lack clarity. By verifying
these details, buyers can ensure they have a precise understanding of
the property they intend to purchase, avoiding potential boundary
disputes and other complications.

[]

ESTABLISHING GOOD TITLE

The clean title certificate, known as "միասնական տեղեկանք" in Armenian,
is a crucial document issued by the Cadastre. It provides a
comprehensive overview of a property's registered ownership and details
various rights and encumbrances associated with it, which may include
liens, mortgages, tenancies, easements, and more. In many cases, this
certificate is the primary document relied upon by buyers during the due
diligence process.
Notably, the clean title certificate holds validity for 15 business
days. Within this timeframe, any necessary agreements, whether
preliminary or final, must be executed. If the 15-day period expires, it
becomes necessary to obtain a new certificate. Any party involved in the
transaction, be it the seller, buyer, or another interested party, can
submit an application for a clean title certificate.
However, it's important to note that certain interests related to the
property, such as easements or rights of heirs, may not always be
entirely verified by the clean title certificate. There could be
individuals with prior acquisition rights or preemption rights
concerning the property sale. Additionally, unauthorized alterations or
additions to the property may not have been declared to the planning
authority, posing potential challenges.
For properties designated for construction, the certificate merely
confirms that the land is zoned for such purposes. Obtaining full
planning consent, often in the form of a building permit, is a
subsequent step required to legally proceed with construction on the
land.

[]

OFFER TO BUY

In Armenia, it's important to be aware that verbal offers or agreements
to buy or sell real property hold no validity and cannot be enforced.
Even a written agreement lacks enforceability unless it has been
authenticated by a notary or a Cadastre official. Therefore, the
standard contract forms typically used by real estate agencies are not
legally binding. Consequently, it is not advisable to make any payments,
such as a deposit, at this preliminary stage.
However, it can be beneficial to prepare a formal written offer to
demonstrate your serious intent and to clarify the terms of the sale.
This written offer can outline key details, including the payment
structure, the earnest money deposit amount, the seller's
responsibilities regarding outstanding utility bills and taxes,
transaction costs, contingencies, and other relevant terms. Essentially,
this written offer can take the form of a draft preliminary agreement,
providing a clear framework for the eventual purchase agreement. While
the written offer itself may not be legally binding, it serves as a
crucial step in the negotiation process and helps establish mutual
understanding between the parties involved in the real estate
transaction.

[]

PRELIMINARY AGREEMENT

A preliminary agreement in Armenia serves as a significant step in the
process of buying or selling real estate. Here are some key points to
understand about preliminary agreements:

1.  Purpose and Function: A preliminary agreement does not transfer
    property ownership but outlines a future date or period for the
    property transfer. It may include conditions (contingencies) that
    must be met before the final closing of the sale. While signing a
    preliminary agreement is not mandatory, it can be beneficial in
    securing a legally binding agreement, especially if you are not
    ready to close the sale immediately.

2.  Importance of Clarity: A preliminary agreement ensures that all
    parties involved in the transaction agree on the terms of the deal,
    helping everyone stay "on the same page."

3.  Contingencies: A preliminary agreement may become necessary when the
    final sale depends on certain contingencies, such as securing
    financing, clearing property liens, conducting appraisals, or
    obtaining specific permits or documents.

4.  Notarization: To be legally enforceable, a preliminary agreement
    must be notarized.

5.  Filing with the Cadastre: While preliminary agreements are generally
    not formally registered, it is advisable to file a copy with the
    Cadastre. This can help minimize the risk of the seller breaching
    the contract by selling the property to a third party.

6.  Deposit Payment: Typically, the buyer pays a deposit to the seller
    at this stage. The specific amount is subject to agreement between
    the parties.

7.  Binding Nature: A preliminary agreement is mutually binding once
    validly signed. Neither party can walk away from the deal unless one
    or more of the specified contingencies are not met. Defaulting on
    the agreement may result in various legal remedies, including
    forfeiture of the deposit. Sellers may be required to pay a penalty,
    often double the deposit amount, for default. In some cases, a court
    may enforce specific performance to compel both parties to complete
    the property transfer as per the agreement.

[]

PURCHASE AND SALE AGREEMENT (DEED OF SALE)

In Armenia, the final sale and purchase agreement holds significant
legal weight and must be executed in the presence of a notary. Here are
important details to consider:

1.  Notary's Role: The notary's presence is essential to validate the
    agreement. Basic agreements may be authenticated directly by a
    cadastral officer, but a notary becomes necessary for customized
    agreements or when one of the parties does not speak Armenian.

2.  Notary's Obligations: The notary is legally obligated to provide you
    with information about the nature and implications of the agreement
    you're signing. They will also need to verify the identity of the
    parties involved and ensure their legal capacity for the
    transaction. This often involves checking the passports (and
    possibly marriage certificates) of all signatories.

3.  Guardianship Considerations: If the seller is a minor, elderly, or
    handicapped and under the protection of a guardian, the approval of
    the guardian will be required before concluding the sale. If the
    seller is married, the notary will also seek confirmation that the
    spouse consents to the sale.

4.  Notary Agreement Templates: Each notary may have their own agreement
    template, and the level of detail can vary. It's crucial to ensure
    that all important clauses are included in the agreement. Typically,
    agreements are in the Armenian language, and verbal translation
    services are provided for a fee.

5.  Final and Comprehensive Agreement: The sale and purchase contract
    should be comprehensive because parties have only 30 days to
    register it at the Cadastre. If there are conditions that still need
    to be fulfilled, it's advisable to sign a preliminary agreement.
    Armenian law does not have "cooling-off" rules, so once signed, the
    agreement is effective and cannot be withdrawn from.

6.  Inventory and Property Inspection: If the purchase includes fixtures
    or fittings, consider preparing an inventory. If possible, visit the
    property a day before signing the agreement to ensure everything is
    as expected, especially if certain fixtures and fittings are part of
    the sale. Also, check that you will get vacant possession of the
    property unless the agreement specifies otherwise.

7.  Power of Attorney: If you cannot be physically present in Armenia
    for the agreement signing, you can grant a relative, friend, or
    lawyer a power of attorney to sign on your behalf.

[]

REGISTRATION

In Armenia, after the final sale and purchase agreement is executed, the
buyer has a critical 30-business-day window to register their ownership
rights with the Cadastre. It's essential to adhere to this timeframe, as
failing to register within the specified period will invalidate the sale
and purchase agreement. Here's what you need to know about the
registration process:

1.  Documentation Required: To initiate the registration process, the
    buyer must provide an original copy of the sale and purchase
    agreement along with a notarized translation of their passport. If
    the registration is handled through a lawyer or another
    representative, a notarized power of attorney will also be
    necessary.
2.  Registration Timeframe: The duration of the registration process can
    vary from a few hours to a few days, depending on whether you opt to
    pay for fast-track service fees.
3.  Ownership Certificate: Once the registration is completed, you will
    receive an ownership certificate. This certificate contains basic
    details about the property and the new owner.
4.  Utility Services Update: Subsequently, you should present the
    ownership certificate to public utility services (such as
    electricity, gas, and phone providers). This step ensures that they
    update their records to reflect the change in ownership and prepare
    new service agreements in your name.

[]

FEES AND TAXES

Notary & Registration Fees: By convention, the buyer typically covers
notary fees and official registration fees, which can range from $200 to
$600. These fees are fixed and do not depend on the property's value.
Fast-track services are available for an extra cost.

|             |             |             |             | Days)       |

| Fee         |             |             |             |             |

+-------------+-------------+-------------+-------------+-------------+

Capital Gains Tax: Transfers of residential property between individuals
are usually exempt from capital gains tax, provided both the buyer and
seller are individuals (not registered as private entrepreneurs). In
such cases, the tax rate on capital gains from residential property
sales is 0%. However, if the buyer is a legal entity or a private
entrepreneur, a 10% withholding tax may apply to the entire transaction
amount.

Sales Tax for Developers: Individual real estate developers are subject
to a 20% sales tax, calculated based on the selling price of the
properties they develop.

Real Estate (Property) Tax: Property owners must pay an annual real
estate tax. Tax rates range from 0% to 1% of the cadastral value, often
lower than the market value. Property tax amounts can be checked on the
Cadastre's website. Recent regulations require sellers to obtain a
certificate confirming the absence of tax liabilities from the local
municipality before registering the sale.

Rental Income Tax: Rental income below 60 million Armenian drams
(approximately US$140,000) per year is taxed at a rate of 10%. Income
exceeding this threshold faces a 20% tax rate.

Effective December 1, 2023, an amendment to the Tax Code of the Republic
of Armenia has been enacted. According to this amendment, failure to
declare and remit taxes for the rental of real estate will result in a
fine for the lessor. The fine is set at 5 percent of the cadastral value
of the property, assessed in accordance with the law and approximated to
the market value, with a cap at AMD 500,000. In the event of a repeated
violation within one year of the initial penalty, a subsequent fine will
be imposed at 10 percent of the cadastral value of the immovable
property, again estimated in accordance with the law and approximated to
the market value, but not exceeding one million drams.

Stamp Duty, Inheritance & Gifts Taxes: Armenia does not impose stamp
duties, gifts, or inheritance taxes.

Communal Charges: Property owners, especially in apartment complexes,
are responsible for maintenance and service charges, which vary based on
property size, quality, and available amenities, such as lifts, pools,
gardens, and other facilities.

[]

MORTGAGE, BANKING & INSURANCE

The possibility of financing your property purchase with a mortgage in
Armenia hinges on several factors: your nationality, your current
country of residence, and the source of your income. Some banks
exclusively cater to Armenian nationals or residents. Typically, you'll
be required to provide a deposit, which can range from 10% to 30% of the
property's purchase price, depending on the lender's policies. Mortgage
terms can extend up to 30 years, affording flexibility in repayment.
Interest rates in Armenia typically average around 10-13% for loans in
the local currency and 8-10% for loans in US dollars.
If you need information about opening bank accounts, please click here.
Regarding property insurance, you can anticipate annual costs ranging
from 0.1% to 1% of your property's value.

[]

CURRENCY EXCHANGE & ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING REGULATIONS

Armenian laws mandate that real property buyers make payments in the
local currency, Armenian drams. If the transaction is conducted through
a bank, it is the responsibility of the bank to ensure compliance with
these regulations.
Currency exchange services are readily available through banks, other
credit institutions, and currency exchange offices.
It's important to note that there are no restrictions on transferring
foreign currency to or from Armenia.
However, when the transaction amount surpasses 50 million drams
(approximately US$105,000), any excess payment must be executed via a
bank transfer.

[]

Considerations for Property Acquisition

When purchasing real estate in Armenia, it's generally a safe process,
but taking specific precautions is advisable:

Marital Status: Be aware of the seller's marital status. If married or
divorced, the spouse's consent may be necessary for the sale. Even if
the property was not acquired during marriage, the spouse or ex-spouse
could claim contributions to property improvements. Armenia does not
recognize common law marriages, but marriages from foreign countries may
pose complications.

Gifts & Inheritance: Investigate whether the property was inherited or
received as a gift. Other family members may contest wills or gifts,
potentially affecting the sale. If children are involved, the
transaction may need approval from the guardianship authority to ensure
it's in the child's best interest.

Capacity to Contract: Pay attention to the seller's behavior. Armenian
law allows courts to declare people with mental disabilities as
incapable. Those addicted to drugs, alcohol, or gambling may have
limited capacity, and agreements with them could be contested. Checking
court records or obtaining a certificate of mental health may be
prudent.

Insolvency: If the seller appears to be in financial distress and sells
below market value, they might be declared bankrupt soon after the sale.
A bankruptcy trustee could challenge the sale within three years. Ensure
the likelihood of bankruptcy is low when purchasing property at a
discount.

Encumbrances and Litigation: While the Cadastre issues a clean title
certificate confirming no mortgages or encumbrances, verify whether the
seller is involved in any property-related litigation before signing the
sale agreement.

Preceding Transactions: Examine the property's history for any
suspicious activities, like frequent transfers within a short period.
Even older transactions can be scrutinized in Armenia, particularly
acquisitions via donations, inheritance, or privatization.

Tax Liabilities and Utility Bills: The seller is obligated to provide a
certificate confirming the absence of tax liabilities from the local
municipality. While new owners are not responsible for prior unpaid
utility bills per law, it might be challenging to establish new
contracts with utility companies if the old bills remain unpaid. Request
statements confirming all utility bills are settled.

Notarization: Consider having the sale contract notarized, even if not
strictly required. Notaries are personally liable for malpractice and
conduct necessary checks, such as consent, valid powers of attorney, and
the seller's mental capacity. Notarization demonstrates good faith if
disputes arise.

Escrow Accounts: Instead of the common practice of cash payments during
the notary's office signing, consider using an escrow account or a
similar tool. This avoids carrying large sums in cash and allows
verification of currency authenticity. Escrow accounts incur additional
bank charges and currency conversion costs, but they can provide
security and transparency in the transaction process. Refer to "Payment
Methods" for more details.

[]

INHERITANCE

In cases where there is no will, Armenian inheritance laws establish a
specific order of inheritance:

1.  Spouse, children, and parents: These individuals take precedence in
    inheriting the estate.

2.  Brothers and sisters (and their descendants): If no spouse,
    children, or parents exist, the next in line for inheritance are
    siblings and their descendants.

3.  Grandparents: In the absence of the above categories, grandparents
    become eligible inheritors.

4.  Uncles and aunts (and their descendants): If none of the preceding
    categories apply, uncles, aunts, and their descendants are
    considered for inheritance.

Each order of inheritors excludes those in other orders, and individuals
within the same order share the inheritance equally. In cases where the
estate owner leaves behind a surviving spouse, two parents, and two
children, each would inherit 1/5 of the estate. It is possible to
enhance the rights of the surviving spouse or children through
inheritance planning.

Spouse: Armenian inheritance law does not offer specific protection to
the surviving spouse. However, typically, the surviving spouse retains
ownership of at least 50% of jointly held assets. Unregistered marriages
may not grant inheritance rights.

Children: Children, regardless of whether they were born within or
outside of marriage, have equal inheritance rights. Adopted children
enjoy the same rights as natural children but cannot inherit from their
biological parents. Grandchildren inherit only if one of the deceased's
children is deceased, in which case they step into their parent's place.

Testamentary Freedom: Under Armenian law, you have the freedom to
dispose of your estate as you wish through a notarized will or gift.
However, certain conditions, such as age restrictions or disabilities,
may allow your spouse, children, or parents to claim 50% of the
property's value in the absence of a will.

Inheritance Planning: To exert control over your estate upon your death,
consider inheritance planning methods, including increasing an heir's
share through a will, making lifetime gifts, purchasing property through
a limited company, or obtaining a life insurance policy.

Taxes: Armenia does not impose taxes on inheritance or gifts. However,
property disposition may be subject to taxation in the heir's tax
residence country unless a double tax treaty exists between Armenia and
that country.

Accepting the Inheritance: Heirs have a 6-month window following the
death to accept the inheritance through a notarized declaration. The
notary oversees beneficiary lists, verifies the existence of a will,
divides the estate, and issues inheritance certificates to the
inheritors.

Executor: You can appoint an executor, such as a lawyer, to manage the
estate. The executor's responsibilities include maintaining and managing
the estate, debt collection, legal representation, ensuring compliance
with the will, and liaising with the notary, among other tasks.

[]

PROPERTY SEARCH

Listings

Property listings in Armenia can be easily found on websites
like estate.am, myrealty.am, bnakaran.com, and list.am. These platforms
offer valuable insights into available properties and their prices,
allowing you to get a preliminary understanding before embarking on your
search.

Before diving into the property hunt, it's beneficial to have a clear
idea of what you're looking for, whether it's a primary residence, a
vacation home, a rental property, or an investment opportunity, as well
as the preferred location, be it in a city or the countryside.

Agents/Brokers

In Armenia, it's customary for agents to charge a commission fee of 2%
to both the seller and the buyer, totaling 4% of the transaction's
value. The buyer typically covers their portion of the commission
separately, in addition to the property's purchase price.

2.  Alex-R

6.  Kentron

8.  Revan
