border_position=”all” padding=”” dimension_margin=”” animation_type=””
animation_direction=”left” animation_speed=”0.3″ animation_offset=””
last=”no”][fusion_text]

Form &  Benefits

The special residence permit (passport) has a validity of 10 years.
It looks very different from temporary/permanent residence permits as it
is issued in the form a passport, not a card. However, all types of
residence permits (temporary, permanent or special) offer more or less
the same benefits. In particular, they allow the holder of the permit to
travel freely to and from Armenia without a visa, to live, work, study,
do business and engage in any other lawful activity in Armenia without
work permits or other papers.

One notable advantage of the special passport is that its holder can own
land directly in his own name, without the need to establish a legal
entity.

Eligibility Requirements 

In practice special passports are issued to foreigners of
Armenian origin, i.e. ethnic Armenians. In exceptional cases special
passports can be issued to non-Armenians who are engaged in economic or
cultural activities in Armenia.

Procedure & Time Line

The procedure of issuing special passports is more complicated compared
to temporary/permanent residence permits and in many aspects is similar
to the procedure for citizenship application. The time required to
obtain a special passport is around 60 days. Unlike temporary/permanent
residence permits the final decision on granting or denying a special
passport is made by the President and cannot be appealed.

[/fusion_text][fusion_imageframe image_id=”7989″ style_type=”none”
stylecolor=”” hover_type=”none” bordersize=”” bordercolor=””
borderradius=”” align=”none” lightbox=”no” gallery_id=””
lightbox_image=”” alt=”” link=”” linktarget=”_self”
hide_on_mobile=”small-visibility,medium-visibility,large-visibility”
class=”” id=”” animation_type=”” animation_direction=”left”
animation_speed=”0.3″
animation_offset=””]https://armenian-lawyer.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Why-Special-Passport.jpg[/fusion_imageframe][fusion_text]

Establishing Armenian Origin

Armenian origin is normally proved by producing a government- or
church-issued document showing the ethnicity of the applicant. A baptism
certificate of the applicant and or his parent (grand-parent) is a
common way to establish Armenian origin.

Children

The children of the holder of a special passport also can obtain special
passports free of charge if they are below the age of 16. Individuals
aged 16 and higher must apply separately.

Extension

The special residence permit can be extended for an indefinite number of
times, each time for 10 years.

Military Duty

Holders of special passports are not considered to be Armenian citizens
and, therefore, are not subject to mandatory military service.

About Us

Welcome to Vardanyan & Partners, your trusted partner in legal matters.
At Vardanyan & Partners, we are committed to providing top-notch legal
services with a focus on integrity, expertise, and personalized
attention for over 10 years. Our team of experienced attorneys is
dedicated to serving the Armenian community and beyond, offering
reliable legal solutions tailored to your unique needs.

Your Privacy Matters to Us
Rest assured, any information you provide will be treated with the
utmost confidentiality. We firmly believe in the principle of data
privacy. That means we will not sell, rent, or lease our contact lists
to any third party, and your personal details will never be handed over
to individuals, government agencies, or companies.

What Makes Armenia a Good Choice for Residency

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

No Stay or Visit

Maintaining residency in Armenia does not require physical presence;
remote application is possible.

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Fast and Easy

The residency application usually takes about 80 days and only a valid
passport is required. 

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Family Covered

Residents can sponsor extended family for residency (parents, siblings,
grandchildren, etc.)
 

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Citizenship Path

After living in Armenia for three years, citizenship can be obtained.
Dual citizenship is allowed.

[]

Where to find us

[]

[]

[]

[]

Nestled in the heart of the Davtashen district in Yerevan, our office is
a stone's throw away from the Migration Service building, ensuring
seamless coordination on immigration matters. If you refer to the map
above, you will pinpoint our exact location. For those journeying from
the city center, anticipate a brief 20-30 minute taxi ride to reach us.
We look forward to welcoming you and addressing your legal needs.

Taxes in Armenia 

Foreign entrepreneurs and investors value the rapidity of economic
reforms, the safety, freedom, and openness that Armenia offers. Many
prefer to visit Armenia in person and register a business as a first
step to enter the market.
Micro-businesses, companies operating within free economic zones,
industrial zones, select border towns, and villages can benefit from a
zero-tax status. Similarly, smaller businesses with annual sales under
approximately $280,000 are subject to a nominal sales (turnover) tax,
ranging from 1.5% to 5%. Remarkably, Armenia follows a lenient tax
policy regarding individual capital gains from the sale of securities,
real estate, and various assets. Additionally, insurance and pension
payments are exempt from taxation, as are gifts, inheritances, and net
worth.
Navigating Armenia's business landscape can be greatly simplified with
the assistance of a knowledgeable local lawyer. These experts play a
pivotal role in minimizing potential risks through meticulous compliance
with tax, labor, and immigration regulations. By harnessing their
expertise, businesses can adeptly sidestep potential pitfalls while
capitalizing on tax benefits and government assistance programs.

Business Tax Options

In Armenia, taxation varies based on the size of the business. Medium
and large businesses adhere to standard tax rates, whereas smaller
enterprises can benefit from special tax regimes designed to alleviate
both the tax burden and paperwork.

Companies can opt for turnover tax or micro-business regimes within 20
calendar days following the registration of the company. 

[]

General tax regime

By default, businesses are subject to the general tax regime, which
includes an 18% corporate income tax (CIT) and a 20% value-added tax
(VAT). VAT is reduced to 0% for goods or services that are exported.
Under this regime, CIT returns are filed annually, while VAT returns
must be submitted on a monthly basis.

[]

Turnover tax

Turnover tax is a form of a sales tax, with rates typically ranging from
1.5% to 5%. It serves as a replacement for both CIT and VAT. However,
this tax regime is only available to small businesses with annual sales
totaling less than AMD 115 million (approximately $280,000). Turnover
tax returns are filed quarterly.

[]

Micro-businesses

Micro-businesses, defined as those with annual sales below AMD 24
million (about $62,000), enjoy exemptions from both CIT and VAT. It's
important to note that certain businesses, such as those located in the
capital city of Yerevan and various service sectors, are excluded from
this tax system and cannot take advantage of these exemptions.

[]

TAXATION OF IT COMPANIES

Newly registered businesses in the IT sector, including both companies
and private entrepreneurs, have had the opportunity to apply for an IT
Start-Up certificate. This certificate holds the potential to offer
significant tax advantages, including a substantial reduction in payroll
tax, lowering the rate of personal income tax withheld by the employer
from the standard 20% to just 10% until December 31, 2024. Currently,
the deadline for applications is November 1, 2024.
To benefit from this program, it's crucial to note that businesses must
apply for the IT Start-Up certificate within 90 days following their
registration. These tax incentives are not accessible to larger
companies with 30 or more employees, or to subsidiaries and branch
offices of foreign companies (these restrictions may potentially be
revised following the passage of new legislation). The issuance of IT
Start-Up certificates is overseen by the Ministry of High-Tech Industry.
The following businesses can take advantage of these tax benefits:

-   Software development, including the creation, modification of
    software, testing and support services; creation of applications for
    clients; development of the structure and contents for systems
    software, applications, databases, websites, or the creation of
    machine commands necessary for such development or operation;
    transformation and adaptation of applications to the information
    environment of the customers;
-   Consulting activities in the area of computer technology, including
    the development and design of computer technical means, software,
    and integrated computer systems in communication technologies;
    services in connection with educating the users;
-   Computer system management activities, including network management
    and creation of computer systems for customers or maintenance of
    technical means for data processing, and other support services;
-   Data processing, distribution of information in the network and
    related activities, including provision of infrastructures for
    website placement; data processing (complete processing of data
    provided by users or through application of original software;
    automated data processing; input services, including database
    management services) and related services; specialized services for
    placement of websites (hosting service), i.e. placement of websites
    in the Web (Web hosting), current transfer of data (undivided,
    according to plans) or placement of applications; operation
    (launching) of software and hardware resources; servicing users
    through a central (global) computer functioning in total
    time-sharing mode;
-   Activities related to web-portals, including activities related to
    websites (use of search engines to create and maintain large-scale
    databases of information located on the Internet with the purpose of
    facilitating easy and accessible searches by addresses or content);
    activities related to other websites that operate as web-portals,
    such as, for example, news websites providing regularly updated
    information;
-   Implementation of educational and research programs in the field of
    information technologies;
-   Design, testing and production of electronic systems;
-   Computer animation and modeling;
-   Design and testing of integrated circuits.

[]

Payroll Taxes

Employers are required to withhold both personal income tax (PIT) and
social security contributions. This encompasses various forms of income
such as salaries, benefits, bonuses, temporary disability compensation,
and maternity leave compensation. As of 2023, a uniform personal income
tax rate of 20% applies to all forms of compensation, regardless of the
amount involved.
Apart from PIT, employers are also responsible for deducting social
security payments. The rate for these payments stands at 5% for income
up to 500,000 AMD (approximately $1,309) and 10% deducted 25,000 AMD for
income exceeding this threshold. It's important to be aware that there's
a maximum salary limit for social security payments, currently capped at
1,125,000 AMD per month (equivalent to 15 times the minimum monthly wage
of 75,000 AMD).
Military taxes (contributions to the insurance foundation of servicemen)
are withheld in the following manner:

-   1,500 AMD ($4) for salaries of up to 100,000 AMD ($261)
-   3,000 AMD ($8) for salaries of 100,000-200,000 AMD ($523)
-   5,500 AMD ($14) for salaries of 200,000-500,000 AMD ($1,309)
-   8,500 AMD ($22) for salaries of 500,000-1,000,000 AMD ($2,619)
-   15,000 AMD ($39) for salaries in excess of 1,000,000 AMD ($2,619)

It's important to note that social security payments and military taxes
are obligations that exclusively apply to Armenian citizens and
residents (i.e. individuals holding residence permits). Generally, those
born before 1974 enjoy an exemption from social security payments.
For instance, in the tax year 2023, consider an employee earning a
monthly salary of AMD 600,000 (equivalent to $1,571). This individual
will be subject to a flat income tax rate of 20% on their entire income,
amounting to income tax of AMD 120,000 (approximately $314).
Furthermore, the employee will be liable for social security payments
totaling 35,000 AMD (around $91) and an additional military tax of 8,500
AMD (approximately $22). Consequently, the after-tax income for this
individual will be AMD 436,500 (calculated as 600,000 - 120,000 -
35,000 - 8,500), which is equivalent to $1143. This results in an
overall tax burden of approximately 27%.

[]

Import Taxes

In Armenia, typically, there's a 20% Value Added Tax (VAT) applied to
imported goods, although some goods enjoy exemptions from this tax.
Notably, for goods imported under government-approved projects, there's
an option to defer VAT payments for a period of up to three years.
Moreover, Armenia is part of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), which
includes countries such as Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan.
Importantly, goods imported from these EAEU member countries are exempt
from import duties. However, when importing goods from countries outside
the EAEU, import duties are imposed based on rates set by the EAEU
Commission.

[]

Other taxes

Armenian companies may be subject to various taxes based on their
specific business activities. These taxes can include excise tax,
environmental tax, road tax, as well as real estate and vehicle property
taxes.

Exploring Residency Opportunities for Digital Nomads in Armenia

With the freedom to work remotely and explore new places, it's no wonder
that more and more people are embracing the digital nomad lifestyle. One
of the key considerations for digital nomads is finding residency
opportunities. In this article, we will delve into the residency
opportunities for digital nomads in Armenia.

[Digital Nomad]

Why Armenia is an attractive destination for digital nomads

Armenia, with its rich history, stunning landscapes, and vibrant
culture, can be a good choice for digital nomads seeking a unique
experience. The country offers a welcoming environment, affordable cost
of living, and a burgeoning tech scene. The capital city, Yerevan, is a
hub for startups and innovation, making it an ideal destination for
digital nomads looking to connect with like-minded individuals.

Residency for digital nomads in Armenia

Although Armenia does not have a specifically designed program for
digital nomads, it does not impose restrictive laws on remote work
within its borders. Digital nomads staying in Armenia for less than 180
days a year do not require any specific permit (work or residence) to
engage in their remote work activities. However, for those interested in
obtaining a residence permit, their remote work can serve as a legal
basis for residency.
Obtaining residency in Armenia as a digital nomad brings a lot of
benefits. Firstly, it provides a legal status in the country making a
lot of procedures in the country, such as opening a bank account,
easier. Secondly, the Armenian law does not require a minimum amount of
days to stay in order to maintain this status. Furthermore, residency
opens up opportunities for business and investment, particularly in
Armenia's thriving tech sector. By becoming a resident, digital nomads
can collaborate with local startups or even launch their own ventures.
Additionally, holding residency for three years uninterruptedly can be a
pathway to citizenship.

Exploring the cost of living and quality of life in Armenia for digital nomads

One of the key factors that make Armenia an attractive destination for
digital nomads is its affordable cost of living which is on average more
than 40% lower than in the US or European countries with its low costs
of accommodation, food and transportation. Additionally, Armenia boasts
a high quality of life, with its safe streets, reliable infrastructure,
and access to modern amenities.
 
Internet availability is crucial for digital nomads, and Armenia meets
this requirement with an average internet speed of 73.55 Mbps. The
country offers several internet providers with competitive and
affordable pricing.

Top cities and regions in Armenia for digital nomads to consider

Armenia's relatively small size does not limit its appeal, as it offers
a diverse range of cities and regions for digital nomads to consider.
Yerevan, with its vibrant atmosphere, numerous co-working spaces, and
thriving tech scene, is a natural choice. Gyumri, the second-largest
city, is known for its rich cultural heritage and artistic community.
Other noteworthy cities and regions include Vanadzor, Dilijan, and the
wine region of Areni, each catering to different preferences and
interests.

Co-working spaces and digital nomad communities in Armenia

Armenia has seen a rise in the number of co-working spaces and digital
nomad communities in recent years, catering to the needs of remote
workers. In Yerevan, you can find a variety of co-working spaces,
offering modern facilities, high-speed internet, and a collaborative
environment. Some popular co-working spaces include Aeon, 256 HUB
Coworking space, Loft, BeCoworker, and "COWO" (Coffee Working). These
spaces not only provide a dedicated workspace but also serve as a hub
for networking and community building.

Conclusion: Unlocking the hidden gems of residency opportunities for digital nomads in Armenia

Armenia offers a unique blend of work and adventure, making it an ideal
destination for digital nomads seeking residency opportunities. Its
affordability, welcoming environment, and burgeoning tech sector make it
a hidden gem for those looking to call it home, at least for a little
while.

Our Proven Process of Making Armenia Your Second Home

1

Preparation

As part of the preparation process, we will take care of translating
your passport, printing photos, and filling out the necessary forms.

4

Residency for Family

You can sponsor your spouse, children, parents, siblings, grandparents,
and grandchildren to obtain residency in Armenia.

2

Investment

In order to qualify for residency, you have the option of either making
a low-risk investment in government bonds or donating to a rural
development project.

5

SSN, Tax ID, Etc.

You can obtain a certificate of registered address, a social security
number, personal tax identification number, as well as a tax residency
certificate.

3

Residence Permit

Applicants can choose to apply for a temporary (1-year) or permanent
(5-year) residence permit remotely or in-person.

6

Bank Account

You can choose from 18 banks offering online and mobile banking, Visa
and MasterCard options, and up to 11% interest on deposits in AMD, RUR,
etc.

Unraveling the Many Facets of Armenia's Vibrant Lifestyle

Armenia, with its harmonious blend of historic charm and contemporary
conveniences, presents a distinctive allure to expatriates. This article
explores the diverse dimensions of life in Armenia, spanning cultural
engagements to professional prospects, providing a comprehensive
perspective on the expatriate experience in this captivating nation.

[]

Professional Avenues and Employment Landscape in Armenia

Armenia is experiencing a rapid growth in various industries, making it
an attractive destination for expats seeking job opportunities. The
nation's pronounced emphasis on technology and innovation has given rise
to a thriving IT sector, earning Armenia the moniker "Silicon
Mountains." An array of international corporations have established
their operations within the country, thus creating a myriad of
opportunities in fields including software development, web design, and
digital marketing.
The administration's proactive stance has engendered favorable policies
like the IT start-up certificate, designed to attract foreign investment
and foster an environment conducive to enterprise with reduced taxation.
This financial incentive extends not only to corporate entities but also
to individual freelancers, ensuring a beneficial tax regimen. Whether
aspiring to conventional employment or aspiring to initiate
entrepreneurial endeavors, Armenia's flourishing economy offers a
spectrum of possibilities.

Cultural experiences in Armenia

Armenia's cultural heritage is a treasure trove waiting to be
discovered. The country is home to ancient monasteries, picturesque
churches, and historic sites that transport you back in time. The
capital city of Yerevan is a hub of art and culture, with its museums,
galleries, and theaters showcasing the best of Armenian talent.
 
Armenia also is rich in festivals during the year catering to a wide
array of interests for foreigners. Starting from Jazz Day held in
Yerevan’s Cascade Complex and Yerevan Wine Days to Vardavar – a
nationwide water festival - Armenia offers many interesting activities
and events to attend and make one’s social life more entertaining and
memorable. 

Expat communities and social life in Armenia

Armenia is a welcoming country that embraces diversity, making it easy
for expats to integrate into the local community. The country has a
growing expat population, with many international organizations and
embassies based in Yerevan. The Armenian people are known for their
hospitality and warmth, and expats often find it easy to make friends
and build a support network. Whether it's attending cultural events,
joining sports clubs, or volunteering for community projects, there are
plenty of opportunities to socialize and engage with the local
community.

Driver’s License in Armenia

Expatriates who have a national driver’s license of the member countries
of the Vienna Convention (please find the list below) can use it to
legally drive in Armenia.
 
1.  Albania
2.  Armenia
3.  Austria
4.  Azerbaijan
5.  Bahamas
6.  Bahrain
7.  Belarus
8.  Belgium

In case you want to apply for an Armenian national driver’s license, you
will need to first become a residence permit holder or a citizen, as
well as you need to take both theoretical and practical exams. The
theoretical exam is currently available in Armenian, Russian, English,
Arabic and Persian.

Insurance companies in Armenia

Although not mandated by legislation, social insurance and medical
coverage are accessible through six prominent insurance providers in
Armenia, namely Armenia Insurance, Ingo Armenia, Nairi Insurance, RESO
Insurance, Liga Insurance (formerly ROSGOSSTRAKH Armenia), and Sil
Insurance.

Traveling within Armenia and nearby countries

Armenia's strategic positioning facilitates not only the exploration of
its own geographical expanse but also neighboring nations. The country's
propitious location makes it an ideal gateway for venturing into
countries such as Georgia and Iran, each presenting its distinctive
cultural tapestry. Additionally, Armenia's geographical advantage has
prompted low-cost carrier WizzAir to initiate direct flights between
Armenia and European destinations, rendering travel accessible and
cost-effective.

Conclusion: Is living in Armenia the right choice for you?

From its rich cultural heritage to its stunning natural beauty, this
small country has much to offer expats seeking a vibrant lifestyle. The
cost of living is affordable and job and business opportunities are
growing. So, if you are ready for a new adventure and want to immerse
yourself in a vibrant and diverse lifestyle, consider making Armenia
your next home.

What Makes Armenia a Good Choice for Residency 

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

No Stay or Visit

Maintaining residency in Armenia does not require physical presence;
remote application is possible.

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Fast and Easy

The residency application usually takes about 80 days and only a valid
passport is required. 

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Family Covered

Residents can sponsor extended family for residency (parents, siblings,
grandchildren, etc.) 

[]

[]

[]

[]

[]

Citizenship Path

After living in Armenia for three years, citizenship can be obtained.
Dual citizenship is allowed.

Our Proven Process of Making Armenia Your Second Home

1

Preparation

As part of the preparation process, we will take care of translating
your passport, printing photos, and filling out the necessary forms.

4

Residency for Family

You can sponsor your spouse, children, parents, siblings, grandparents,
and grandchildren to obtain residency in Armenia.

2

Investment

In order to qualify for residency, you have the option of either making
a low-risk investment in government bonds or donating to a rural
development project.

5

SSN, Tax ID, Etc.

You can obtain a certificate of registered address, a social security
number, personal tax identification number, as well as a tax residency
certificate.

3

Residence Permit

Applicants can choose to apply for a temporary (1-year) or permanent
(5-year) residence permit remotely or in-person.

6

Bank Account

You can choose from 18 banks offering online and mobile banking, Visa
and MasterCard options, and up to 11% interest on deposits in AMD, RUR,
etc.

Armenia, which has been providing excellent legal services since its
establishment in 2012. Our team of locally licensed, English-speaking
attorneys specializes in immigration, incorporation, and compliance
matters, ensuring that clients receive expert legal guidance.  We are
committed to staying up-to-date with the latest changes in legislation
and regulations, ensuring that our clients receive the most relevant and
accurate advice. At Vardanyan & Partners, we place a strong emphasis on
honesty, transparency, and client care.

A Digital Nomad's Guide to Renting an Apartment in Armenia: How to Protect Yourself from Fraud?

[]

As a digital nomad, renting an apartment in a foreign country can be
quite challenging. There are many things to consider, including the
language barrier, cultural differences, and the risk of falling prey to
rental scams. Armenia is no exception, and it's important to take the
necessary precautions to protect yourself from rental scams.

Legal Requirements of Renting in Armenia

In Armenia, it is crucial to adhere to certain legal requirements when
renting an apartment. According to Armenian law, rental agreements
should be registered in the Cadaster. If the tenant does not speak
Armenian, it is necessary to sign the lease agreement at a notary with
the assistance of a translator, followed by registration in the
Cadaster. The notary will also request a joint reference from the
lessor, verify the lessor's ownership or authorization, and confirm
spousal consent to the transaction.
Regarding the contents of the contract itself, it is important to
clarify matters such as utility payment responsibilities, early
termination procedures, repair responsibilities for both the tenant and
the lessor, liability for damages caused to neighbors during the lease,
frequency of landlord inspections, and the conditions for returning or
forfeiting the advance payment, among other relevant aspects. To avoid
future disputes regarding contract termination, it is also advisable to
formalize its resolution through a notary.
As for the government fees, the fees for the registration in the
Cadaster are AMD 26,000 (around USD 65). The government fee paid in the
notary in case of verification of lease agreements is AMD 1,000 (around
USD 3) and the service fees charged by the notary can vary from AMD
8,000 - 25,000 (around USD 25 - 65).
While some of these formalities may not be strictly necessary for
short-term leases, they are important for long-term agreements because
failure to register the right to lease (such as having an oral or
unofficially written agreement, or a notarized agreement not registered
in the Cadaster) implies that the agreement does not legally exist,
thus, tenants will have no legal means to protect themselves and
landlords can demand eviction at any time or increase the rent
arbitrarily.
Nevertheless, it should be noted that many lessors in Armenia prefer not
to sign contracts with a notary to avoid paying a 10% tax on rent. In
some cases, if the lessor agrees to register in the Cadaster, they may
increase the rent by the same percentage. It is important to acknowledge
that, in practice, most lease contracts in Armenia are not registered.

Tips for Renting an Apartment in Armenia

Before you rent an apartment in Armenia, there are several things you
should consider.
First, utilize resources available for finding secure apartments in
Armenia. Reliable platforms like Airbnb and Booking.com offer secure
payment options and provide a review system where you can access
feedback from previous guests.
Additionally, local real estate agents can be valuable allies in your
search for a secure apartment, guiding you through the rental process
and ensuring your safety. Please note that in Armenia, real estate
agents do not require licenses, which increases the risk of fraud.
Therefore, it is wise to work exclusively with reputable agencies to
minimize the chances of encountering fraudulent practices.
Second, recording the initial condition of the apartment through
photographs or videos is recommended to prevent disagreements about the
property's condition upon acceptance and return.
 
Lastly, it should be noted that after July 1st, 2023, cash payments for
real estate related transactions will no longer be permissible.
Consequently, the landlord is obligated to accept non-cash payment
methods. Additionally, it is important to mention that lessors can only
accept payments in the local currency.

Conclusion

In conclusion, renting an apartment in Armenia as a digital nomad
requires careful attention to legal requirements and precautions to
protect yourself from fraud. Adhering to Armenian law, such as
registering rental agreements in the Cadaster and signing leases at a
notary, provides crucial legal protection. Utilizing reliable platforms,
working with reputable agencies, documenting the apartment's condition,
and adhering to non-cash payment methods are all essential steps for a
safe and secure rental experience in Armenia. By taking these
precautions, digital nomads can navigate the rental market with
confidence and peace of mind.

The Ultimate Guide to Tax Residency in Armenia for Digital Nomads

Tax residency holds great significance for digital nomads, requiring
careful consideration to ensure optimal financial outcomes.

[]

Why choose Armenia for tax residency?

Armenia has emerged as an appealing choice for digital nomads seeking
advantageous tax conditions. Notably, the country boasts low tax rates,
levying a mere 5% tax on dividends for tax residents, while interest
income is taxed at 10%. Moreover, Armenia generally refrains from
imposing taxes on capital gains from the sale of securities, real
estate, and other assets, regardless of the origin of these gains.
Certain income sources, including insurance and pension payments, also
enjoy tax exemptions, alongside exemptions on gifts, inheritances, and
net worth. Another notable advantage of Armenian tax residency lies in
its extensive network of double taxation treaties, spanning
approximately 50 countries.

Understanding the requirements for tax residency in Armenia

To establish tax residency in Armenia, it is essential to comprehend the
criteria outlined by the Armenian tax authorities. According to Armenian
tax laws, two avenues exist for attaining tax residency and obtaining a
tax residency certificate, which serves as proof of one's tax residency
status. The first path deems an individual a tax resident if they spend
a minimum of 183 days in Armenia during a fiscal year.
An alternative route to securing a tax residency certificate involves
petitioning the tax office, even without fulfilling the 183-day
requirement, by substantiating that one's center of vital interest is
based in Armenia. As per the law, the center of vital interests is the
place where a person's family or economic interests are concentrated.
Specifically, if an individual's family resides in Armenia or if their
primary property or main economic (professional) activity takes place in
Armenia, the center of vital interests is considered to be in Armenia.
In simpler terms, if an individual can establish that their ties to
Armenia are stronger than their ties to any other country, they could
obtain a tax residency certificate even if they spend less than 183 days
in the country.

Tax residency certificate application process

Once one of the abovementioned criteria are met, an individual can apply
for a tax residency certificate at the Tax Service of the Republic of
Armenia. In order to do so, it is necessary to provide copies of
relevant documents indicating income received from abroad, as well as
copies of all passport pages. The Tax Service may also require
additional documentation as per their discretion.
Alternatively, the application for the tax residency certificate can be
submitted through a Power of Attorney, thereby eliminating the
requirement for physical presence. Upon submission of the application, a
response can be expected within two business days.
It should be noted that the tax residency certificate is issued
specifically for the particular year.

Tax obligations for digital nomads in Armenia

Digital nomads who acquire tax residency in Armenia bear certain tax
obligations. Generally, upon applying for a tax residence certificate,
individuals must declare the income they received from abroad in the
respective year. If taxable income has been obtained, an income tax
report must be submitted to the State Revenue Committee by April 20 of
the subsequent year.
Tax residents are liable for taxes on their worldwide income. However,
if taxes have already been paid in the country where the income was
earned, individuals are granted a tax credit equivalent to the taxes
already paid in that foreign jurisdiction. In other words, if the tax
rate in the foreign country surpasses that of Armenia, it is unlikely
that any taxes will be payable in Armenia.

Common misconceptions about tax residency in Armenia

The most common misconceptions surrounding tax residency in is that
obtaining a residence permit (temporary, permanent, or special)
automatically makes you a "tax resident". However, it is crucial to note
that tax residency is regulated by tax laws, not immigration laws.
Consequently, an individual only attains tax residency upon fulfilling
the requirements outlined in this article. Thus, it is possible to
possess a residence permit without being a tax resident, and vice versa.

Conclusion: Is tax residency in Armenia right for you?

Tax residency in Armenia can prove advantageous for digital nomads
seeking a low-tax jurisdiction that offers an appealing quality of life.
The country's straightforward tax system, expansive double tax treaty
network, and affordable cost of living render it an enticing
destination. Nevertheless, each digital nomad's circumstances are
unique, necessitating careful consideration of personal factors, tax
obligations, and long-term plans before reaching a decision.

What Makes Armenia a Good Choice for Residency

Navigating the Digital Nomad Visa Process: How to Become a Resident of Armenia

[Digital Nomad]

Every country has its own set of immigration rules and regulations,
making the process of obtaining a visa a daunting task. However, in
recent years, many countries have recognized the benefits of having
digital nomads in their economy. One such country is Armenia.

Introduction to Digital Nomad Visas

A digital nomad visa is a type of visa that allows remote workers to
work and live in a foreign country for an extended period. The visa is
perfect for people who can work from anywhere as long as they have a
laptop and an internet connection. Digital nomad visas are becoming
increasingly popular among remote workers as they provide an opportunity
to travel and work simultaneously.

What is the Digital Nomad Visa for Armenia?

Armenia allows remote workers from a number of countries to live and
work in Armenia visa-free for up to 180 days. Remote workers who stay
past the 180-day deadline can register as “private entrepreneurs” and
obtain one-year (temporary) or five-year (permanent) residence permits.
The above rules apply whether you are a freelancer, remote worker, or
self-employed. There is no minimum monthly income to show. However, an
immigration officer may want to make sure you are able to cover your
living expenses in Armenia.

Benefits of Obtaining a Digital Nomad Visa

Obtaining a digital nomad visa for Armenia comes with several benefits.
Firstly, Armenia is a beautiful country with a rich history and culture.
The country has a low cost of living, making it an affordable
destination for digital nomads. Secondly, Armenia has a fast and
reliable internet connection, which is crucial for remote workers.
Thirdly, the Armenian government is supportive of remote workers and has
introduced several initiatives to attract digital nomads to the country.
For instance, the government has introduced tax exemptions for newly
registered IT businesses, including “private entrepreneurs.” Lastly,
Armenia is strategically located between Europe and Asia, making it an
ideal base for digital nomads who want to explore both continents.

Requirements for Obtaining a Digital Nomad Visa in Armenia

To obtain a digital nomad visa (residence permit) in Armenia, you must
meet the following requirements:
1.Be a freelancer, remote worker, or self-employed
2.Register with the State Registry (an agency operating under the
Ministry of Justice) as a “private entrepreneur”
3.Pay taxes on income attributable to your Armenian business (unless you
are exempted from taxes)
4.Have a medical check certificate
5.Have a valid passport
6.Submit an application form
The residence permit application fee is AMD 105,000 (around $270) for a
temporary (one-year) permit and AMD 140,000 (around $365) for a
permanent (five-year) permit, and the processing time is approximately
45-55 days.

The Process of Obtaining a Digital Nomad Visa (Residence Permit) in Armenia

The process of obtaining a digital nomad visa (residence permit) in
Armenia is relatively straightforward. Firstly, you need to collect the
following documents:
1.A valid passport,
2.A notarized translation of the passport
3.A copy of the visa (or e-visa) or the entry stamp in your passport if
you are exempt from visa requirements.
4.A medical check certificate
5.Passport-sized photos (3)
6.Certificate of registration as “private entrepreneur” (or an LLC if
you prefer to set up a company in Armenia)
Next, you need to submit the above-mentioned documents to the
Citizenship and Migration Service․ To do so, you will need to book an
appointment online using a local cell phone number. You will also need
to fill out an application form in which you will need to specify the
nature of your activities, your address in Armenia and abroad, phone
numbers, email address, citizenship, ethnicity, marital status, and the
type of residence permit you are applying for (temporary or permanent).
In addition to the application form you will also need to write a short
cover letter and a written consent to process your personal data.
Alternatively, you can give a power or attorney to your lawyer or other
representative to handle the paperwork.
You will pay the government fees at the time of the application.
The processing time is approximately 45-55 days. If your application is
approved, you will receive a residence permit that is valid for one year
(temporary permit) or five years (permanent permit).

Living in Armenia: Cost of Living and Lifestyle

Living in Armenia is affordable compared to many other European
countries. The cost of living is low, and you can enjoy a comfortable
lifestyle without breaking the bank. Armenia is a safe country, and the
people are friendly and welcoming to foreigners. The country has a rich
cultural heritage, and there are many historical sites to explore.
Additionally, Armenia has a vibrant food scene, and you can try out
different cuisines at affordable prices.

Armenia Citizenship by Investment

As of 2023, Armenia has plans of offering citizenship by investment
(CBI) to foreign investors who invest at least $150,000 in the country’s
economy. The citizenship by investment program offers several benefits,
including visa-free travel to over 60 countries, and the right to live
and work in Armenia. While the approval of the CBI program is still
pending digital nomads have the option of acquiring citizenship through
regular naturalization procedures after three years of residency in
Armenia. 

Conclusion: Is the Digital Nomad Visa (Residence Permit) for Armenia Right for You?

Armenia's digital nomad visa is an excellent option for remote workers
who want to explore a new country and culture. The visa is easy to
obtain, and the cost of living is affordable. Additionally, Armenia has
a fast and reliable internet connection, making it an ideal destination
for digital nomads.
If you plan to stay in Armenia for an extended period, you can apply for
a temporary resident permit or a PR card. In conclusion, if you are a
digital nomad looking for a new destination, Armenia should be on your
list. The country offers a unique blend of history, culture, and
affordability that is hard to find in many other countries.

What Makes Armenia a Good Choice for Residency

Maintaining residency in Armenia does not require physical presence;
